profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 30, 2019 at 02:00

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous letters collection

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

langmaterial.language: Most items are in English, but some are in French, German, and other European languages. Letters that are not in English have been coded for language.

did.abstract: Miscellaneous Letters Collection is a collection of hundreds of individual letters or small groups of letters, mostly by physicians and scientists, either donated to the Historical Library or purchased.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains individual letters or small groups of letters from the correspondence of scientists, physicians, and other health practitioners. Provenences vary greatly. Some were donated by collectors or descendents of the recipient, others purchased, and others removed from books in the Historical Library in which collectors had placed them. Most letters were acquired in the period before 1960. Members of the Beaumont Medical Club collected and donated letters related to Connecticut medicine. John F. Fulton, in particular, purchased individual letters from book stores and book sellers for the collection. A number of the letters in the collection are to and from Yale School of Medicine faculty members. There are also some letters by Yale medical students and alumni. Of particular note in this collection are letters on inoculation and vaccination for smallpox, and on anesthesia.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Letters, with a few exceptions, are arranged alphabetically by author.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Yale does not own copyright to letters in this collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was initially organized by Madeline Stanton, Librarian of the Historical Collections from 1939 to 1968. Her annotations have been transcribed to the new folders.

did.unittitle: Ackland, A. A., Silver Creek [Indiana?], to P. M. Barrows, Oberlin, Ohio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About the death of his patient and dear friend, Henry B. Clark. Letter contains a detailed case narrative.
The letter was the gift of Sidney Withington in January 1959, whose wife was a descendent of the recipient.

did.unittitle: Acland, Henry W., to Mr. Gross

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry Acland was Regius Professor of Medicine at Oxford to 1895. E. Ray Lankester left the Linacre professorship of comparative anatomy at Oxford in 1898 to become director of the British Museum. (Natural History). Letter by Henry Acland is to an unidentified recipient discussing raising funds for a public health building and the search for a successor to Lankester.
The letter was removed from John Fulton's copy of Acland's Oxford and Modern Medicine, 1890.

did.unittitle: Addams, Charles, New York, to Clements C. Fry, two letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning Fry's purchasing of drawings by Addams, a cartoonist for the New Yorker.

did.unittitle: Aiken, Arthur [London], to [James?] Asperne [London]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of Arthur Aikin on behalf of the Society of Arts to [James?] Asperne thanking him for portraits for the Society. Aikin does not have a portrait of himself to furnish but will be available if Mr. Drummond (an artist?) should call. Gift of L. Cohen, Argosy Books, 1952.

did.unittitle: [Alsop, Charles Richard] 5 letters to Charles R. Alsop

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charles Richard Alsop graduated from Yale College in 1821 and practiced law in Middletown, Connecticut. The folder contaians letters to Charles Richard Alsop from his sister, Lucy Chauncey, his mother, and Charles Woodward of Middletown, Connnecticut, discussing a yellow fever scare attributed in part to Yale medical professor, William Tully, family matters, social life in Middletown, the illness and death of Lucy Chauncey's daughter, Clara, en route to Valparaiso, social life in Valparaiso where Lucy Chauncey settled with her family, quarantine of ships for cholera in Valparaiso, Alsop's engagement to Margaret Armstrong, and Mrs. Dana's eye problems. The letters were the gift of Mrs. Kenneth McKenzie, granddaughter of Charles Richard Alsop, 1956.

did.unittitle: American Laryngological Society, 2 letters to Henry L. Swain, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters signed by James A Babbitt and Charles J. Imperatori, successive secretaries of the American Laryngological Association, concern Swain's election to Honorary Fellowship. Gift of Henry L. Swain.

did.unittitle: Andrews, Charles M., East Dover, Vermont, to John E. Lane, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Review of a book in French on French hospitals in the colonies from 1777 to 1784. Lane was interested in French physicians serving in the Revolutionary war.

did.unittitle: Aschoff, Ludwig, to Dr. Charles H. Bunting

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Charles H. Bunting, January 1953.

did.unittitle: Astruc, Jean, Toulouse, to "Monsieur"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of Jean Astruc to an unknown correspondent excusing his absence from an unnamed scientific society and presenting the society with a geometric problem transmitted by a geometer in the area. Removed from the Library's copy of Astruc, Mémoires pour servir a l'histoire de la Faculté de Médecine de Montpellier(1767).

did.unittitle: Babinski, Joseph, Paris, to [Edgar?] Berillon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Joseph Babinski to [Edgar?] Berillon thanking him for the invitation to the next meeting of the Societe d'Hypnologie. He has nothing to present but will attend. Gift of John F. Fulton, 1950.

did.unittitle: Baillie, Matthew, to Mr. Bliss, Surgeon, Hampstead [England]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Matthew Baillie to Dr. Bliss requesting a description of the symptoms of a patient for a friend who wished to publish an account of the case. The letter includes a reply by Bliss in which the symptoms and account of the illness are described.
Purchased from Hamill de Barkes, June 1962.

did.unittitle: Barbauld, Mrs. Anna Letitia, S. Newington, England, to Mrs. Carr

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Mrs. Barbauld to Mrs. Carr confirming a visit for two or three days. Letter was removed from John Fulton's copy of Memoirs of Mrs. Barbauld (London, 1874).

did.unittitle: Beddoes, Thomas, 2 letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters of Thomas Beddoes to an unnamed physician, n.d., and to Dr. Currie, Liverpool, 1802 October 21, discussing medical cases and praising Erasmus Darwin's Zoonomia. Letters purchased by John Fulton from Myers & Co. and donated, February 1957.

did.unittitle: Beddoes, Thomas, [Bristol], to Mr. Phillips, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of Thomas Beddoes to Mr. Phillips discussing his own illness. Letter has the stamp of the Bristol Post Office. Donated before April 1948, probably by Arnold C. Klebs.

did.unittitle: Bernard, Claude, Paris, to the Dean of the Faculté de Médecin, Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: His children are sick with scarlet fever and he excuses himself from leaving Paris to go to Douai.

did.unittitle: Bigelow, S. J. [?], Paris, to J. Mason Warren, Boston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bigelow's mother is in Paris and suffering from tuberculosis. He requested that his mother consult Warren who was studying abroad at the time.

did.unittitle: Blackwell, Elizabeth, [New York], to Katie

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elizabeth Blackwell received her medical degree from Geneva Medical College in 1849. She then traveled to England and France to continue her study of medicine, returning to New York in August 1851. The letter, written to her "very dear friend" Katie who is otherwise unidentified, mentions her recent return after two years' absence and her wish to renew their friendship.

did.unittitle: Blair, William, [London], to W. Bedwell [London]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from William Blair to W. Bedwell asking him for further information on the accusation he had made to the Royal Jennerian Society against Dr. Walker. Dr. Walker had been acquitted by the Society. Dr. Walker was presumably John Walker, Secretary of the Royal Jennerian Society. Letter was purchased from Old Hickory Bookshop (Acc. 25714).

did.unittitle: Blumer, George, correspondence with Abraham Flexner and others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On setting up the full-time plan at Yale with money from the Rockefeller Foundation. Blumer was Dean of the Yale School of Medicine from 1910 to 1920. Folder also includes Blumer to John Fulton, 1951 April 10, Blumer to Ira V. Hiscock, 1958 April 22, and a reprint by Blumer, "Brief Recollections of the Yale Medical School (1906-1920)," Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine, 21[5] (May 1949): 365-376.

did.unittitle: Blumenbach, Johann Friedrich, Gottingen, to ?,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter may be incomplete as there is no salutation. Recipient name is illegible.

did.unittitle: Boerhaave, Herman, Leiden, to "Mijn heere"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Boerhaave to an unnamed recipient thanking him and praising him for a book he has written. With the letter is an unrelated envelope with seal in Boerhaave's hand addressed to a student named Outhuis. Letter (and envelope) purchased by John F. Fulton from Pierre Beres, Inc., Paris, 1947. Correspondence concerning the purchase is included in the file.

did.unittitle: Boyle, Robert, to "Madam"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: According to the book dealer's description, the letter asks a "Lady" to intercede with the French Ambassador to procure him a passport. Apparently after the execution of Charles I and the beginning of the Civil War, Boyle wanted to leave the country. Letter was probably obtained for the Library by John Fulton. The Library owned the letter before 1962.

did.unittitle: Bright, Richard, [London], to John Bostock

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Richard Bright to John Bostock thanking him for his complimentary dedication in a recent publication. Dr. John Bostock dedicated his Sketch of the History of Medicine (1835) to Richard Bright. The letter was the gift of Dr. Richard Hunter to John F. Fulton, 1956.

did.unittitle: Bright, Richard, to Dr. Maclaggin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brief letter from Richard Bright to Dr. Maclaggan asking him to write. Sent to John Fulton by E. Weil, May 1949.

did.unittitle: Brown-Séquard, Charles Edouard, [Paris], to "Cher Monsieur"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of Charles Edouard Brown-Séquard to an unnamed gentleman discussing the votes lined up for him for a major election, presumably to membership in the Académie des Sciences. Brown-Séquard was elected to the Académie in 1886. A typed Engish translation of the letter is available. Letter purchased from Old Hickory Booksellers, 1957.

did.unittitle: Brown-Séquard, Charles Edouard, New Brunswick, N.J., 2 letters to Dr. Bache, Jr. [Thomas Hewson Bache]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first letter concerns a possible exchange of journal volumes. The second requests a reference to obtain the chair of physiology at the future Cooper Union for the Advancement of Sciences and Art (founded in 1859). The letters were purchased from Argosy Books.

did.unittitle: Burggraeve, Ad[olphe], Gand, [Belgium], to [Jean-Baptiste] Nothomb, Ministre de l'Interieur
Butler, John Simpkins, Hartford, to L. Tupper, Esq.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John S. Butler, a graduate of Yale College in 1825, was Superintendent of the Connecticut Retreat for the Insane. The letter discusses the "hard case" of Ellen O'Brien who is unlikely to improve.

did.unittitle: Buttner, Jacques L., Les Boyers, France, to Dr. Scobie[?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jacques L. Buttner graduated from Yale School of Medicine in 1909. He discusses in his letter the good luck that brought him to Yale and how he decided to become a doctor, and what has since happened. He also mentions Horace Fletcher and discusses diet. The recipient appears to be a fellow alumnus, possibly Russell B. Scobie who graduated from the Medical School in 1929.
Madeline Stanton noted that the letter was brought to the Library by Dr. Arthur Ebbert.

did.unittitle: Callow, W. J., Liverpool, to Sir Astley Cooper [London]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from W. J. Callow to Astley Cooper on a case of a dislocated humerus that he treated and for which the patient also consulted Cooper and a bone setter. Cooper's reply is written on the letter. Purchased by Harvey Cushing from Maggs Brothers, London.

did.unittitle: Canning, Edward, to Rev. Josiah W. Canning, Gill, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Edward W. B. Canning to his father, Rev. Josiah W. Canning, on the birth of his child using ether anesthesia and on family matters. Letter is headed "Bulletin No. 2." Purchased by John F. Fulton from Symmachus Trading Company, Boston, June 1952.

did.unittitle: Cardwell, P. H., Knoxville, Tenn., to E. E. Miller, agreement for dental training

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: E. E. Miller will be admitted for three months to the dental practice of "Dr. P. H. Cardwell" for instruction and access to books and instruments for the fee of $50.

did.unittitle: Carmalt, William H., Rainsford Island Hospital, Boston, to "Dear Sir"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lengthy account of an unusual gynecological and obstetrical case. Carmalt later became professor of surgery at Yale.

did.unittitle: Chambers, William Frederick, to Dear Sir,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Short note saying that he can't see the patient until 4:00 the next day. With this is a cut fragment with signature from a letter to a Mr. Miller. Gift of L. Cohen, Argosy, 1952.

did.unittitle: Chapman, Nathaniel, [Philadelphia], reference for his former student Dr. Martin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dr. Martin had studied medicine under Chapman and had graduated at the last commencement of the University of Pennsylvania where Chapman served as a professor.

did.unittitle: Charcot, [Jean Baptiste August Etienne], Paris, to "Cher Monsieur"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Madeline Stanton thought the author was the son of Jean Martin Charcot. Gift of H. W. Liebert, March 1957, in memory of C. C. Fry.

did.unittitle: Charcot, Jean Martin, Paris, to "Cher collegue et ami"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charcot asked that the recipient be extremely indulgent to young Vigues who is undergoing his examinations. He is the son of a good friend. Letter was the gift of John Fulton, 1959.

did.unittitle: Charcot, Jean Martin, Paris, note to B. W. Austen [?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Charcot presents his compliments to M. B. W. Austen or Austin, who may have requested a signature. Also in the folder is a note on two eminent physicains and scientists and an engraving from a magazine of Charcot. Madeline Stanton suggested that this material may have been collected by Harvey Cushing's father, Henry Kirke Cushing.

did.unittitle: Chase, Salmon P., U. S. Treasury Department, to Alexander Jamieson, Collector of Customs, Alexandria, Va.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chase sends his Civil War regulations approved by Congress concerning permits for transport and trading with those who are in "insurrection." Letter purchased from Forest H. Sweet, December 1958.

did.unittitle: Chase, Salmon P., Washington, D.C., autograph sentiment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "He that ruleth over men must be just, ruling in the fear of the Lord." Purchased from Forest H. Sweet. Gift of John Fulton, 1959.

did.unittitle: [Chastenet de] Puységur, [Armand-Marie Jacques], near Soissons, to [Joseph] Deleuze, Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Puységur's successes on treatments by mesmerism. Letter was either from Clements C. Fry or purchased with funds donated by him.

did.unittitle: Choulant, Ludwig, Dresden, to Karl Wilhelm Dindorf
Clark, J. A., to "My dear Boot"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mentions Dr. Warren, natural history, and Dr. Jackson, so he may be referring to John Collins Warren and Boston.

did.unittitle: Cline, Henry, to Mr. Birch

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry Cline was a London surgeon. He is setting up an appointment to see Mr. Birch. Gift of L. Cohen, Argosy Books, 1952.

did.unittitle: Cobb, J. C., New Orleans, to his family, Sharon, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cobb is writing to his father and family from New Orleans, where he is a surveyor. He mentions his recent marriage. Most of the letter concerns his contracting smallpox, the progression of his symptoms, and his treatment with the help of his wife.
Letter purchased from Symmachus Trading Co., Boston, by John Fulton and Madeline Stanton in October, 1951.

did.unittitle: Cogswell, James, New York, to Levi Hart, Preston, Conn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: James Cogswell was a surgeon in the American Revolution and the brother of Mason Fitch Cogswell. The letter concerns some shipments to Scotland being made by Cogswell for Hart, and the death of Hart's wife, Rebecca. From the J. G. Bell and Sir Thomas Phillipps collections. Gift of John Fulton, 1959.

did.unittitle: Colladon, Jean-Pierre, Sécheron [Geneva, Switzerland], 2 letters to Alexander Marcet, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The letters discuss the illness of their mutual friend, Dr. A. Aubert, and Aubert's efforts to introduce vaccination for smallpox into France, as well as the first vaccination in Switzerland. Letters purchased from Bader, May 1958.

did.unittitle: Colton, Gardner Quincy, New York, to Benson J. Lossing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: At the request of historian Benson J. Lossing, Colton's letter provides a lengthy account of his career and his version of the discovery of anesthesia, for Lossing's proposed history of New York. Purchased from Whitlock Americana, New Haven, June 1960.

did.unittitle: Combe, George, Edinburgh, to Ed. McGlashan[?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cover letter for a requested testimonial. Removed from Clements C. Fry's copy of Charles Gibbon, Life of George Combe.

did.unittitle: Coomes, Sexton P., New Haven, to his brother

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lengthy letter written when Coomes was a freshman at Yale College on family matters, farming, a fire caused by student reveling, and the typhoid fever epidemic. Coomes says the newspaper coverage of the typhoid epidemic at Yale is exaggerated. However, Coomes succumbed to typhoid fever before his freshman year was over. Donated to the Library by Mrs. Lucene (Cecil H.) White, a great niece of Coomes, September 1987. Typed transcript available.

did.unittitle: Cooper, Astley, [London], to the Duke of Wellington

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Astley Cooper to the Duke of Wellington asking permission, as trustee of the Royal College of Surgeons, to dedicate a book to him. Praises Wellington's support for military medicine. Purchased from Myers, February, 1955.

did.unittitle: Corrigan, Dominic, Sir, Dublin, to "Sir Wm."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Sir Dominic Corrigan to an unknown recipient thanking him for introducing him to Dr. Tiemsin? of Aachen. He has put him in contact with "some of the best men here." Gift of Bern Dibner, March 1969.

did.unittitle: Crawford, Albert Beecher, Yale University, to Maxwell Bogin, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Crawford, who was Director of the Bureau of Appointments at Yale, awarded Bogin the William A. Rogers scholarship for the following year. Also included is a letter from the benefactor, William A. Rogers, Buffalo, to Maxwell Bogin, 1922 October 18. Bogin graduated from the Sheffield Scientific School in 1923 and from Yale School of Medicine in 1926. The letters were donated by Deborah Bogin Cohen, Boston, in 1999.

did.unittitle: Cushing, Caleb, Washington, D.C., 2 letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters of Caleb Cushing of the Trustees of the College of Physicians and Surgeons in the City of New York, 1840 March 10, and to the Dean of the Medical Faculty of Transylvania University, 20 April 1841, recommending Dr. Elisha Bartlett for a position on the medical faculty. Letters given to Harvey Cushing by Miss Agnes Willard, August 14, 1927.

did.unittitle: Dam, Carl Peter Henrik, Copenhagen, to W. T. Salter, Yale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henrik Dam (1895-1976), was a Danish biochemist and physiologist who shared the Nobel Prize in 1943 with Edward Doisy for his work in discovering vitamin K and its physiological function. The letters to Salter, chair of the Department of Pharmacology at Yale, relate to Dam's seminar lecture at Yale School of Medicine on September 20. The two letters (one a receipt) are dated September 20, 1951 and October 1, 1951. Letters are the gift of William T. Salter, October 26, 1951.

did.unittitle: Darwin, Charles, Down House, Kent, to George Ransome

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopy. The original is in the William Finklestein Autograph Collection, Manuscript 19th cent+, Medical Historical Library. In response to a circular from a museum, Darwin is forwarding an order.

did.unittitle: Darwin, Charles, Down, Beckenham, Kent, to [John Weldon?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requests purchase of two books on anthropology. Copy in file. The original is tipped into the Historical Library's copy of Charles Darwin, "On the movements and habits of climbing plants," extracted from Journal of the Linnean Society, 1867, 9: [1]-118. Recipient and year were suggested by the Charles Darwin Correspondence Project.

did.unittitle: Darwin, Charles, Down, Kent, 3 letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters of Charles Darwin to [Henry Denny], [20 July 1844], sending him packets of lice; to Richard Owen, [ca. 1848] asking to meet with him to obtain his opinion on "a few zoological points"; and to [C.H. Blackley?], 9 March 1877, thanking him for his essay and admiring his calculation of the weight of pollen grains. Recipients and dates have been identified by the staff of the Darwin Correspondence Project.
Letter to Denny was removed from John Fulton's copy of On the Origin of Species, (New York, 1860). Letter to Owen was the gift of John Fulton, 1954.

did.unittitle: [Darwin, Charles] Henrietta Litchfield, Down [Kent], to Camilla [Pattrick]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Henrietta (Darwin) Litchfield to Camilla [Pattrick] informing her of the death of her father, Charles Darwin. Camilla (Ludwig) Pattrick was the German governess who taught Henrietta and the younger Darwin children in the 1860s. She married Reginald Saint Pattrick, an English vicar. Identification of the recipient made by staff of the Darwin Letters project.
Gift of John S. Kebabian, August 1959.

did.unittitle: Darwin, Erasmus, Lichfield [England], to his son, Charles Darwin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Long letter to his son who is studying medicine on his view of the pulse. Letter donated by John Fulton.

did.unittitle: Davy, Humphry, 2 letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One letter is to A. Carmichael, [no year] November 12, on light rays and electricty. There is a transcription and the original casing that the letter came in from the dealer with an engraving of Davy and a separate signature. The second is to "Dear Sir," 1816 March 10, and invites the recipient to a meeting of the Royal Institution. Purchased from R. King, May 1940.

did.unittitle: Dexter, Franklin B., New Haven, to Walter R. Steiner (2 letters)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Franklin B. Dexter had been Secretary of the Yale Corporation. The letters relate to W.M. Hand's diary at Yale in 1809-1810.

did.unittitle: d'Herelle, Félix, 8 letters to George H. Smith

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Donated to the Historical Library by Miriam Smith, daughter of George H. Smith, in 1992. An accompanying photograph of d'Herelle given to Smith has been transferred to the Photograph Collection. d'Herelle was professor of bacteriology at Yale from 1928 to 1933.

did.unittitle: Dieulafoy, Georges, Paris, to Albert Calmette, Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Georges Dieulafoy (1839-1911) was a noted Paris physician. Albert Calmette was director of the Institut Pasteur. The letter was presented to John F. Fulton by Dr. E. Rosencrantz, November 1, 1950.

did.unittitle: Doremus, Robet Ogden, New York, 2 letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1888 letter to "Mr. Griswold, Chairman of the Banquet Committee" declines an invitation for an entertainment of the Delta Kappa Epsilon Society. The 1896 letter to the Governor of New York (Levi Morton) on stationery of the College of the City of New York, requests support of a bill for another year of funding of the New York Pasteur Institute under Dr. Paul Golier. The Institute provides free treatment for rabies to residents of the state who have been bitten by rapid animals and are unable to pay. The letters were the gift of L. Cohen, Argosy Books, 1952.

did.unittitle: Drake, Daniel, to "My dear son"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of introduction for Dr. W. H. Lee, a graduate of the Medical Institute of Louisville. According to Madeline Stanton, the letter was from the collection of Harvey Cushing.

did.unittitle: Duckworth, Dyce, Sir, London, to Charles G. Ruttie, San Francisco

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With a printed clipping of Duckworth's biography. Gift of J. Cohen, Argosy Books, 1952.

did.unittitle: Dunglison, Robley, Philadelphia, to [Joshua] Cohen, Baltimore

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to Dr. Cohen introducing Dr. Brown-Séquard, with envelope. From Harvey Cushing's collection.

did.unittitle: Ehrlich, Paul, to Reid Hunt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter seems to have been sent by Hunt to Harvey Cushing. Includes a note by Reid Hunt, Boston. Annotations by Cushing[?] and Madeline Stanton.

did.unittitle: Ehrlich, Paul, to "Lieber college"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With typed English translation. Donated in 1977 by A.V. Piccirillo, M.D. "In appreciation for the kind interest and support to Donald J. Cohen, M.D."

did.unittitle: [Elie de Beaumont, Léonce] Invitation to his marriage to Madame du Bouchet née Quelen
Fairfield County Medical Association to Francis Bacon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed invitation hand-signed by A[?] E. Wordin, Secretary. Francis Bacon was a Yale surgeon. The Fairfield County Medical Association dated from the founding of the Connecticut (State) Medical Society in 1792.

did.unittitle: Faraday, Michael, Royal Institution, London, to R. Young,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Middlesex Hospital. Young was a physician at the Hospital. Letter purchased by john Fulton in 1937.

did.unittitle: Ferrier, David, [London], letter of recommendation for Dr. James Taylor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of recommendation by David Ferrier for Dr. James Taylor who had applied for the position of medical officer at the Adelaide Hospital. There is no recipient specified. Letter was the gift of F.M. R. Walshe, London, to John F. Fulton, October 1951.

did.unittitle: Fischer, Emil, Karlsbad, to Max Bergmann

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Removed in 2007 from Joseph Fruton's copy of Emil Fischer, Untersuchen uber Depside en Gerstoffe(Berlin, 1919).

did.unittitle: Fischer, Hermann, Munich, 2 letters to Arnold C. Klebs, Nyon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Forbes, Edward, to [Richard] Owen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Fothergill, John, 11 letters to his brother, Alexander Fothergill

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Donated by James W. Osborn, Department of English, Yale University, to John Fulton for the Historical Library, December 1948.

did.unittitle: Francis, S. W., Belleville [Ontario], to My dear Friend

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The letter writer is a physician and surgeon who invites his friend to visit. He hopes to write a book on the principles of surgery and asks for advice on having it published. He may be Samuel Ward Francis (1835-1886).

did.unittitle: Frank, Johann Peter, Pavia, [Italy], to Monsieur

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift of Arnold C. Klebs.

did.unittitle: Galton, Francis, to John G. Blumer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift of former Yale medical dean George Blumer, November 1950. The recipient was Blumer's father. In his letter to Fulton, dated November 20, 1950, Blumer explained the context of the letter.

did.unittitle: Galton, Francis, 4 letters to Moncure D. Conway

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Moncure David Conway was an American abolitionist, a Unitarian minister, and a writer. The letters, along with three Galton memoirs "Generic Images" (1879) and "Hereditary Genius: The Judges of England Between 1660 and 1865" (1869), and "Pedigree of Darwin" (1886 or after), appear to have been purchased by Edward C. Streeter at the "Moncure Conway Sale." They were donated by Streeter to the Historical Library in July 1941.

did.unittitle: Gardiner, Silvester, Newport, R.I., to Messrs. Angell & Jackson, Providence, R.I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to Messrs. Angell & Jackson, merchants, seeking to recover interest on the rent of his house during the Revolutionary War. Gift of H. W. Liebert, September 1959.

did.unittitle: Geikie, Archibald, Sir, 2 letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The earlier letter from "Industrial Museum" to "My dear Sir" refers to a geological paper he read at the Royal Society last night. He would prefer to have it printed in full in the Proceedings rather than the Transactions. The second letter from "Shepherd's Down, Haslemere, Surrey," is to "Professor Bonney," whom he thanks for "taking us to everything interesting." Madeline Stanton noted that the provenence of these letters was unknown.

did.unittitle: Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, Etienne, Paris, to Henri Dutrochet, Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to Henri Dutrochet agreeing to subscribe to a book (Dutrochet's?). Removed from the Library's copy of Etienne Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, Etudes progressives d'un naturaliste (Paris, 1835).

did.unittitle: Gilbert [?], Solomon, Providence, R.I., to Dr. Erastus Osgood, Lebanon, Conn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Solomon Gilbert[?] to his brother or brother-in-law, Dr. Erastus Osgood, discussing politics and family matters.

did.unittitle: Gosse, Edmund, London, to William Osler

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses the health of Henry James for whom he served as physician. Removed from the Historical Library's copy of Edmund Gosse, Father and Son (New York, 1907).

did.unittitle: Gregg, Alan, Rockefeller Foundation, New York, to Takeo Inouye, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thanks Inouye for his hospitality to Dr. Fujinami of the Visiting Committee of Japanese medical scientists when he was in New Haven.

did.unittitle: Guérin, Jules, to "Cher Ami" [?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brief note. "Ami" might be "Ann." Gift of George Milton Smith.

did.unittitle: Haller, Albrecht von, Gottingen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Several letters or fragments. Three are in French and probably all to Francois Boissier de la Croix de Sauvages (dated 1752 September 10, 1752 September 12, and 1755 November 7). These were purchased from a bookseller, probably by Arnold C. Klebs. Two other fragments, probably also obtained by Klebs, are in German, and dated 22 October 1755 and 14 December 1756. One is addressed to the Professor of Theology at Helmstadt. Yet another leaf is said to be the concept paper for Haller's Historia stirpium indigenarum Helvetiae inchoata (Berne, 1768).

did.unittitle: Halsted, William S., Baltimore, to Arnold C. Klebs, Washington, D.C., 2 letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One letter disusses the contributions of Theodor Kocher and the other the possibility of raising funds to bring Klebs to Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. Halsted encloses six photographs of "the fauna and flora of our camp in the North Carolina mountains."

did.unittitle: Halsted, William S., Baltimore, to O.T. Osborne, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the biliary calculus that Osborne sent for Halsted's collection.

did.unittitle: Hamilton, Alice, Hadlyme, Conn., to Earle M. Chapman, Boston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed on U.S. Department of Labor stationery. Alice Hamilton, M.D. was known for her work on industrial diseases. She thanks Dr. Chapman, who was associated with the Massachusetts General Hospital, for an article on the effect of turpentine on the kidneys of painters.

did.unittitle: Harvey, Samuel C., correspondence on Nathan Smith

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typed letter (carbon copy) to Raymond Hussey, Brady Laboratory, Yale, July 14, 1915; typed letter (carbon copy) to Walter R. Steiner, Hartford, July 14, 1925, and autograph typed letter from Steiner to Samuel Harvey, on the Beaumont Medical Club and collecting material related to Nathan Smith and Connecticut medicine. Harvey was professor of surgery at Yale.

did.unittitle: Haskins, Charles H., Cambridge, Mass., to Edward C. Streeter, two letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Hauy, Valentin, to Fougeroux de Bondaroy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On being allowed to present a paper on education of the blind at the Académie in Paris. Letter donated by John Fulton, 1957

did.unittitle: Hawley, Joseph R., Chairman, U.S. Senate Committee in Military Affairs, to O. T. Osborne, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He has received Osborne's letter "concerning that part of the Army Reorganization Bill relating to tthe Medical Corps."

did.unittitle: Helmholtz, Hermann von, Berlin, to [?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Helmholtz, Hermann von, Charlottenburg, to [?]
His, Wilhelm, Leipzig, to Emil du Bois Reymond, two letters

did.unittitle: Holland, Henry, Sir, [London], to "Dear Sir"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Holmes, Oliver Wendell, [Boston], to "Dear Sir"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Holmes, Oliver Wendell, Boston, to Mr. Forbes

did.unittitle: Holmes, Oliver Wendell, Beverly Farms, Mass., to "My dear Sir"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to an unnamed recipient requesting, if possible, the return of an unpublished poem that the recipient had mentioned. Holmes claimed he wrote one or two poems in his youth that he did not wish to be published.

did.unittitle: Hooker, Charles, New Haven, to L. R. Welles, State Prison, Wethersfield, Conn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hooker, professor of anatomy and physiology at the Medical Institution of Yale College, asks Welles, warden of the Connecticut State Prison in Wethersfield, that if any death in the prison occurs, to give us "timely notice," as according to a state statute. Hooker is seeking bodies for teaching [i.e. dissection].

did.unittitle: Horsley, Victor, Sir, [London], to R. Fielding Ould, Oxford

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On "Miss Cobbe," probably Frances Power Cobbe, an anti-vivisectionist and writer on religious and moral issues.

did.unittitle: Howard, John, to "Sir"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the plague. From or purchased from R. W. Chapman, Oxford, March 1947.

did.unittitle: Howell, William Henry, Baltimore, to "Miss Rosencrantz"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On medical research. Presented by Dr. Fulton by Dr. E. [Esther?] Rosencrantz, November 1, 1950.

did.unittitle: Howitt, William, to Alleyne Maynard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Invitation to go on a long "ramble." "From Dr. Cushing's collection."

did.unittitle: Hubbard, Thomas, Hartford, to Sir

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dr. Hubbard, chair of surgery at Yale from 1829 to 1938, wants to procure a copy of a medical and surgical dictionary. The letter was donated to the Historical Library by Samuel C. Harvey, a later chair of surgery.

did.unittitle: Hudson, W. H., London, to Edward Garnett

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: About Sir James McKenzie's advice on Hudson's heart condition. Hudson and Garnett were writers. Letter given by E. Byrne[?] Hackett of the Brick Row Book Shop to Harvey Cushing. Included is a letter from Hackett to Cushing, December 24, 1936.

did.unittitle: Hughes, Thomas, to "Sir"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Humphry, George Murray, Sir, Cambridge, to Dr. Hooker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From Bern Dibner, March 1969.

did.unittitle: [Hunt, Willis R.] Four letters to Willis R. Hunt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The letters are: Marian Dale, Harvard School of Public Health, to Hunt, 1932 April 7; Hans Zinnser, Harvard Medical School, to Hunt, 1932 April 12; Hans Zinnser to Hunt, 1932 June 6; and Leroy D. Fothergill, Children's Hospital, Boston, to Hunt, 1932 June 20. The letters were donated by Willis R. Hunt in December 1967.

did.unittitle: Hunter, John, to Sir Joseph Banks, two letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dates of letters are 1788 July 13 and 1788 September 2. Purchased by John F. Fulton from Halliday, 1937.

did.unittitle: Hurd, Henry M., Baltimore, to O. T. Osborne, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter written on the letterhead of The American Journal of Insanity. Hurd praises Osborne's reprint, "The Progress of Medicine."

did.unittitle: Ingalls, William, Boston, to Tyler Briggs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tyler Briggs is addressed as "Student of Medicine." The letter concerns Ingalls's treatment for dysentery fever. It was purchased by John F. Fulton from Symmachus Trading Co., Boston, in 1951.

did.unittitle: Jenner, Edward, Berkeley, [England], to "Dear Madam" [Lady Ducie]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: According to a letter from William LeFanu to John F. Fulton, 13 January 1956, the recipient was the wife of the first Earl Ducie. Her eldest daughter, Lady Mary Moreton married the 7th Earl of Denbigh in May 1822. The letter discusses the case of Lady Denbigh who was vaccinated but contracted smallpox. Jenner notes the improvements made in his methods of vaccination since vaccinating Lady Denbigh. Purchased by John F. Fulton from M. Sinelnikoff, New York, July 1954. Typed transcript available.

did.unittitle: Jenner, Edward, Berkeley, [England], to Gardner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Edward Jenner to Gardner, otherwise unidentified, inviting him to attend on the day appointed for "spider smothering."

did.unittitle: Jenner, Edward, to Charles Parry, Crescent, Bath

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Edward Jenner to Charles Henry Parry reflecting on disease, sorrow, and death in his own family and in that of Parry, and in particular on the suffering of Parry's father, Caleb Hillier Parry.
Purchased from Zeitlin & Verbrugge, Los Angeles, 1959. Typed transcript available.

did.unittitle: Jennings, Hargrave, [London], to "Dear Madam"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift of L. Cohen, Argosy, 1952.

did.unittitle: Johnston, John, Wesleyan University, Middletown, to Messrs. Hezekiah Howe & Co.

did.unittitle: Jones, Henry Bence, London, to Dr. Becker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Jowett, Benjamin, Oxford, to [E. Ray Lankester]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Keen, William Williams, Philadelphia, to Walter R. Steiner, Hartford

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Keith, Arthur, Sir, Royal College of Surgeons, London, to Mrs. Thorne

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Keith wrote to Mrs. Thorne, "Your father deserves all you can do for his memory." The letter was given to Fulton by Dr. Backer. Folder contains also a letter from John F. Fulton to Sir Arthur Keith, 1954 January 7, asking who Mrs. Thorne was; Keith's reply, 1954 January 12, saying that he did not recall; and Fulton's response, 1954 January 16. The 1954 letters also discuss the death of the anthropologist Ralph Linton and the Piltdown man affair.

did.unittitle: Kershaw, Richard, Central London Throat and Ear Hospital, 2 letters to to Dr. Macintyre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On how Dr. Kershaw handles asking patients for contributions toward their care. The letter was removed from the Historical Library's copy of Richard Kershaw, Special Hospitals (London, 1909).

did.unittitle: Kingsbury, John A., Milbank Memorial Fund, to C.-E. A. Winslow, New Haven, and reply

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On public health reports made by Sir Arthur Newsholme in the counties of Gloucester and Cambridge, England.

did.unittitle: Kneeland, Samuel, Mass. Institute of Technology, Boston, to I. I. Hayes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kneeland, a physician and naturalist, asks the Arctic explorer, I. I. Hayes, M.D., to join him on a trip to Iceland. Letter was purchased from W. R. Benjamin, September 1941.

did.unittitle: Knight, Jonathan, New Haven, to Dr. David B. W. Shaw, Woodbury

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Knight plans to travel to Woodbury on Tuesday and perform the operation on Wednesday. He makes suggestions to Dr. Shaw on how to treat the patient before the operation. Letter from H.W. Liebert, March 30, 1965.

did.unittitle: Knighton, William, Sir, Windsor Castle, to Charles Bell

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thanks Bell for two papers on the nerves and says that he has no chance of becoming acquainted with the physician Bell mentions. Purchased from Myers & Co., January 1950. Also a postcard by Myers & Co. offering another Knighton letter.

did.unittitle: Kronecker, Hugo, to Charlotte Kronecker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift of Mme. Charlotte Kronecker to John F. Fulton, November 1946.

Laennec, R. T. H., to Monsieur Pillet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With an additional half sheet that may or may not be related. Removed from Laennec, Propositions sur la doctrine d'Hippocrate (Paris, 1804),

did.unittitle: Larrey, D. J., Koenigsburg, to [?], Chirurgien Mayer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Removed from L.-J.-B. Béringer-Féraud, Le Baron Hippolyte Larrey (Paris, 1899). Letter may be missing the bottom portion.

did.unittitle: Lewes, George Henry, 9 letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters dated Dresden, 1858 July 23 and 1859 March 1, are to John Chapman. The first describes his travels and visits with anatomists and physiologists. Two letters may be to T. H. Lacy and the remainder are to unidentified recipients. Five letters have been transcribed by Gordon Haight.

Purchased by John F. Fulton from Myers & Co., London. Folder includes correspondence among Meyers & Co., Gordon Haight, and Jonn Fulton, 1951-1953, and a sheet of writing which has a newspaper notice of the George Henry Lewes Studentship founded in memory of Lewes to support research in physiology.

did.unittitle: Lindsey, Theophilus, London, to William Tayleur, Shrewsbury

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Joseph Priestley, religion, and a plan for a new seminary.

did.unittitle: Lister, Joseph, Baron, 2 letters to Mrs. Bishop

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the illness and death of her husband Dr. Bishop. Purchased by John F. Fulton from H.K. Elliott, London, August 1956.

did.unittitle: Lister, Joseph, Baron [London], to Sir William Osler

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On making a list of American surgeons of special distinction and Osler's mother's 100th birthday. Removed from Sir Rickman John Godlee, Lord Lister (Oxford, 1924).

did.unittitle: Lister, Joseph, Baron, to W. B. Holderness [incomplete]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two pages on preventing putrefaction of wounds. The first part of the letter is missing. The folder contains additional materials on the provenance of the letter which was removed from Holderness's copy of volume 3 of St. George's Hospital Reports. These include a letter from Sir W. Hale White to W. B. Holderness, 1914 January 28; a copy of a letter from Harvey Cushing to Archibald Malloch, New York Academy of Medicine, 1930 March 4; a letter from Eric Bligh (bookseller) to John F. Fulton, 1930 March 9. Also related is a photostat of a letter in the Osler Library from Lister to Malloch, 1868 September 10.

did.unittitle: Loewi, Otto, New York, to William T. Salter, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thanks Salter for his hospitality in New Haven where he received an honorary degree from Yale University in 1951. He includes two brief accounts of the dream that led to his experiment on the frog's heart, showing the chemical transmission of the nervous impulse. Also included is a copy of the Commencement Program inscribed by Loewi to the Department of Pharmacology at Yale. Gift of William T. Salter, June 18, 1951.

did.unittitle: Lovell, Joseph, Washington, D.C., to Col. Thomas Aspinwall, U.S. Consul at London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From the bequest of Harvey Cushing.

did.unittitle: Lowe, John, Gull, William, and Jenner, William, bulletin on the state of health of the Prince of Wales

scopecontent.p: "His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales has passed a tranquil morning. The Symptoms are still favorable." Signed by William Jenner, M.D., William Gull, M.D., and John Lowe, M.D. Letter donated by Bern Dibner, March 1969.

did.unittitle: Luc, J. A. de (Jean André), London, to Alessandro Volta, Pavia, and reply by Volta

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fourteen-page letter by de Luc on electricity and Volta's six-page reply. Letters purchased by john Fulton from Bader, Geneva, ca. 1948.

did.unittitle: Lyell, Charles, to Gideon Mantell

did.unittitle: Lyell, Charles [London], to [?]

did.unittitle: Macaulay, T. B., Albany, to "My dear Sir"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Mailhouse, Max, New Haven, to Henry L. Swain, New Haven

did.unittitle: Malpighi, Marcello, Bologna, to "Illustrissimo et Eccelentissimo Signor"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With typed transcript and translation. Purchased by John Fulton, September 1956, in Florence, Italy, via J. Zeitlin.

did.unittitle: Malthus, Thomas R., to J. L. Mallet, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter concerns population, poverty, statistics, and the work of Sir Francis d'Ivernois. Purchased from Goodspeed's Book Shop, Boston, ca. 1965.

did.unittitle: Marcet, Alexandre-John-Gaspard, 8 letters and documents to and by Marcet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marcet was a physician and chemist who lectured at Guy's Hospital, London. Documents include: Printed resolution addressed to Marcet and hand-signed by William Livingston, naming him an honorary member of the Aberdeen Medical Society, 1808 October 20; C. Duméril, Secrétaire de la Société de Médecine de la Faculté de Paris, to Marcet, naming him a corresponding member, 1816 August 27; Acloque [a firm], Paris, to Marcet, 1820 July 14 and 1820 August 31; Henry Lemercier, pharmacien-manufacturier de produits chemiques, to Marcet, 1820 July 14; Pixii [firm], Paris, to Marcet, 1820 August 1; printed pamphlet to Fellows of the Royal Society, on the politics of electing a new Chair and discouraging private attempts to select Humphry Davy, 1820 November; handwritten copy of Marcet to C. Duméril, membre de l'Institut, Paris, [no year] September 14.
Purchased from Libraire Ancienne P.-L. Bader, May 1958. See also letters to Marcet under Louis Odier and Jean-Louis Prévost.

did.unittitle: Marie, Pierre, to Esther Rosencrantz, San Francisco

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With envelope; and carbon copy of letter from Esther Rosencrantz to Pierre Marie, 1928 November 18.The letters concern Dr. Rosencrantz leaving a copy of a memorial volume to Sir William Osler (to which she had contributed) at Pierre Marie's home in Paris for him to sign.

The folder also contains Esther Rosencranz's reminiscences of Pierre Marie, undated; Esther Rosencrantz to John Fulton, 1948 November 16; and a copy of letter from John Fulton to Esther Rosencrantz, 1948 November 7. Dr. Rosencrantz donated Pierre Marie's letter to John Fulton and the Historical Library.

did.unittitle: Martin, H. N., Woodville, to Dr. Benjamin D. Neill, near Tchula, Holmes County, Mississippi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newsy letter by Martin, a physician and seller of drugs. Letter sent to John Fulton by Mr. Ralph Hubell, October 8, 1938.

did.unittitle: McCormick, Harold, Chicago, to George M. Smith, Pine Orchard, Conn.
Mease, James, Philadelphia, to Messrs. C.W. Karthaus, Kurts & Co., Baltimore

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On behalf of the Horticultural Society of Philadelphia, Mease would like to forward a packet containing a letter to the horticultural society at Brussels and a copy of the Philadelphia society's Constitution to a similar society being formed in Amsterdam. He hopes for a friendly exchange of trees, plants, and seeds. The letter was the gift of J. Cohen, Argosy, 1952.

did.unittitle: Mesmer, Franz Anton, to Monsieur le Marquis de Chefdebièn, Narbonne or Carcassonne

Folder also includes a printed broadside, Translation of Dr. Muspratt's American Diploma, University of Maryland (Liverpool: Henry Greenwood, Steam Printing Works, ca. 1858).

did.unittitle: Moffatt, Thomas, New London, Conn., to Dudley Woodbridge, Norwich, Conn.

With Frances Edwards to Fulton, 1941 February 11, and a page on Thomas Moffatt, a Scotch physician who emigrated to America in 1746.

did.unittitle: Monsey, Messenger, Norwich, to Lady Walpole

did.unittitle: Moore, Norman, London, to Dr. Cock

did.unittitle: Morgan, Charles F., Greenville, Michigan, certification that Samuel E. Morgan pursued the study of medicine and surgery under him for three years

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Samuel Ernest Morgan graduated from the Medical Institution of Yale College in 1875. This certification was probably sent to the medical school in fulfillment of the requirements for graduation. This is a late example of a medical apprenticeship, as this was no longer required at Yale after 1879.

did.unittitle: Morrison, Albert, to Clarissa E. Morrison, and letters and receipts to Albert Morrison

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Albert Morrison (1820-1873), born in Hebron, Connecticut, was attending the Pittsfield Medical College, when he wrote to his sister Clarissa, asking for monetary help and discussing visiting her. He graduated from the College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York City, in 1847, and practiced in Windsor, Connecticut. The folder also contains four letters to Morrison and a receipt, (1) from his mentor Dr. M. L. Libbie of Broad Brook, Conn., 1847 February 1, sending Morrrison his certificate of apprenticeship [not in the folder] and discussing Morrison's forthcoming medical school examination; (2) from C. F. Vincent, Tariffville, Conn., 1851 April 5; and (3-4) two invitations to annual meetings of the Hartford County Medical Society, from H.S. Fuller, clerk, 1871 April 10 and 1872 April 20. The receipt is for dues from the Connecticut Medical Society, 1866 April 10.

did.unittitle: Mott, Valentine, New York, to Dr. De Rosset [?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mott responds to a case presented to him by another doctor. De Rosset may be Dr. Armand John De Rosset (1767-1859). Also included in the file is a signed slip, "Address to the Academy of Medicine on retiring from the Presidency." From the bequest of Harvey Cushing.

did.unittitle: Müller, Friedrich Max, Oxford, to E. Ray Lankester

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning having a Medical Faculty at Oxford in addition to a finishing school for gentlemen. Purchased from I.K. Fletcher, September 1942.

did.unittitle: Naegeli, [Otto?] Kantonsspital Zürich, to Arnold C. Klebs, Nyon
Neander, Gustaf, Stockholm, to Arnold C. Klebs, Nyon
Needham, Joseph, University of Cambridge, to C. N. H. Long, Yale University School of Medicine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter supports the application of Dr. Gwei-Djen Lu, for a research fellowship in biochemistry at Yale. He praises Dr. Lu, a Chinese woman biochemist, who received her Ph.D. from Cambridge, as "one of the best Chinese minds" in biochemistry. She later became Needham's chief co-author and much later his wife.

did.unittitle: Nightingale, Frances, South W. Park Lane, to "My dear Sir"

did.unittitle: Noyes, Burr, New Haven, 3 letters to Charles L. Mills, Fairfield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Burr Noyes and Charles Lewis Mills both graduated from Yale College in 1924. The letters were written while Noyes was a medical student at the Medical Institution of Yale College. He mentions Jonathan Knight's anatomy class. Noyes received his M.D. in 1827. The letters were donated by Miss Catherine Curtis, Charlottesville, Va., a great niece of Mills, in 1967.

did.unittitle: Odier, Louis, Geneva, 8 letters to Alexandre-John-Gaspard Marcet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dr. Louis Odier of Geneva brought cowpox from England to the Continent and used the term "vaccine." Letters, which mention inoculation for smallpox, were purchased from Bader, May 1958.

Craig, and an unidentified author. Presumably these letters were sent to Harvey Cushing who was writing Osler's biography.

did.unittitle: Peaslee, Edmund Randolph, 11 letters to Amassa Farrington Kinne

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edmund Randolph Peaslee graduated from Dartmouth College in 1836 and from the Medical Institution of Yale College in 1840. This series of letters were written during the end of his studies at Dartmouth through his time as a medical student at Yale. Kinne graduated from Dartmouth College in 1837 and was a roommate of Peaslee. He obtained his M.D. from Dartmouth in 1840. The letters were donated by Genevieve K. Bartlett, widow of Dr. Charles J. Bartlett, of New Haven. Extracts were published by Herbert Thoms, "Some Letters of of Edmund Randolph Peaslee B.A. Dartmouth 1836, M.D. Yale 1840," Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine, 17[6] (July 1945): 685-704. The folder includes the original letters, transcripts, and correspondence of Mrs. Bartlett and Herbert Thoms concerning biographical material on Kinne.

did.unittitle: Pershing, John J., 9 letters to Rev. Charles S. McFarland, Federal Council of Churches, New York, and others concerning chaplains in the Army and Navy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

The letters were purchased by George Milton Smith and donated to the Historical Library in June and July 1950. Included in the folder is correspondence between Smith and John Fulton concerning the gift.

did.unittitle: [Silliman, Benjamin] Three letters to Silliman by George Jones and W. Turk concerning a remarkable case of resuscitation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: W. Turk, formerly surgeon of the frigate President, recounts at length the case of a sailor William Kemble, aboard the frigate, who was just pronounced dead on January 17, 1814, but then addressed his messmates on moral issues. "Resuscitation was never known after putrefaction had commenced." The folder contains George Jones to Silliman, 1836 October 19, with a copy of a report made by W. Turk, and two letters by Turk to Silliman on the resuscitation, 1836 August 1, and 1836 November 30. The letters were puchased from Argosy Book Stores, New York, in April 1949.

did.unittitle: Smith, J. Talcott, Hanover [Dartmouth] Medical College, 11 letters to Captain Chauncy Barnard, Hartford

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These letters are mostly about Smith trying to obtain payment from Barnard for oats. Several of the letters mention Dr. Nathan Smith. "Letters from the collection of Dr. Walter Steiner, secured by Dr. [Herbert] Thoms from the Steiner Sisters."

did.unittitle: Smith, Nathan, Hanover, N.H., to Mason F. Cogswell, Hartford, Conn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Response by Nathan Smith, professor at Darmouth Medical School, to letters from Mason F. Cogswell, a leading Hartford physician and surgeon. Smith had been offered the position of professor of medicine and surgery at the Medical Institution of Yale College which would begin its first session in the fall of 1813. Cogswell had been offered the position previously but had turned it down. Smith discusses anatomical preparations and books for the new school and an epidemic disease in the Hanover area. He plans to meet Cogswell in person. This letter is the gift of Archives and Special Collections, University of Louisville, 2017.

did.unittitle: Smith, Nathaniel, Philadelphia, to Nathan Smith, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nathaniel Smith (1762-1822) and Nathan Smith (1770-1835) were brothers born in Woodbury Connecticut. Both became lawyers and politicians in Connecticut. Nathan Smith, a judge, served as U.S. Senator from Connecticut from 1833 to 1835. Nathaniel Smith served as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives from 1795 to 1799. This letter, written presumably when Nathaniel Smith was in Congress in Philadelphia, concerns a legal case of Baron & Curtis. The letter refers to Benedict and Daggett.

did.unittitle: Smith, Nathaniel, Woodbury, to Nathan Smith, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See note for previous folder. Nathaniel Smith is concerned about the health of his son Nat who is studying in New Haven. He is worried that the doctor by his treatments has "driven the disorders of his body into his head," and asks his brother in New Haven to report on his health.

did.unittitle: Watkins, Samuel C. G., Letters received, A-H

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Watkins was a dentist in Montclair, New Jersey, who wrote to notables mainly to get their autographs. In this group of letters to physicians, medical philanthropists, and public health promoters, Watkins asked various general questions to get the recipient to respond. For example, he posited a nephew in high school and asked whether medicine was a good field to enter. Other questions concerned public health based on recent news. Some recipients answered at length. Letter writers have been arranged alphabetically.

Writers in this folder include Donald B. Armstrong, W. H. Bates, George Emerson Brewer, Alexis Carrel, William E. Chenery, Emile Coué, H. S. Cumming, William Darrach, George Draper, David L. Edsall, Kendall Emerson, Nelli B. Foster, Louis I. Harris, and Floyd G. Haviland.

These letters seem to have been sent from Sterling Memorial Library to the Historical Library some time before 1968. They are related to the Samuel C. G. Watkins Autograph Collection (MS 698) at Manuscripts and Archives.

scopecontent.p: Given to John Fulton by Dr. Esther Rosencrantz, November 1950.

did.unittitle: Welch, William Henry, Baltimore Club [Baltimore], to Dr. L. K. Musselman

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Luther Kyner Musselman received an M.D. from Johns Hopkins in 1919 and a Ph.D. from Yale in 1923. Welch accepts the invitation of the Yale Chapter of the Gamma Alpha Fraternity to a dinner at the Graduate Club. Folder includes envelope and a copy of the cartoon, "Some Welch Rabbits." Donated by Dr. Musselman, January 1964.

did.unittitle: Welch, William Henry, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, to Arthur H. Ruggles, Butler Hospital, Providence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two copies of what might be a facsimile letter. Welch agrees "to preside at the twentieth anniversary dinner commemorative of the founding of the mental hygiene movement." Refers to Clifford Beers. Received from Ira Hiscock some time before 1967.

did.unittitle: Welch, William Henry, Baltimore, to O. T. Osborne

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the letterhead of theJournal of Experimental Medicineof which Welch served as editor. This may relate to Osborne's request to become a member of a society.

did.unittitle: Whipple, George H., Rochester, New York, reference for William J. Messinger for a Yale fellowship

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reference for the Alexander Brown Coxe Memorial Fellowship for Research in the Biological Sciences, Yale University School of Medicine.

did.unittitle: Williams, Clark, Lebanon, Conn., to Capt. James Powers, Waterford, Conn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Williams asks Powers if the traveling physician Moses Hale, who claimed to have "cured" Powers's wife of "the Consumption," is truthful or an "imposter." Hale has not thus far helped Williams's "complaint."
Letter was purchased by John Fulton from Mrs. Frances Edwards, Suffield, Conn., January 1951. Correspondence on the purchase is included in the folder.

did.unittitle: Williams, Francis H., Boston, to O. T. Osborne

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sends Osborne an abstract (not included) of what he had the pleasure of presenting at the Yale Medical Alumni Association on March 28.

did.unittitle: Wilson, William C., Philadelphia, 2 letters to Eugene Carter, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Prof. William Wilson" has a system of "nerve cure" described in print on the back of his stationery that cures a wide variety of conditions. He sends Carter an "Actina," which includes a battery for use for his eyes. Wilson claims myopia or nearsightedness can be cured with it.

did.unittitle: Winslow, Forbes Benignus, Hammersmith, London, 17 letters to Sir John Philippart

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters undated. Processed by Madeline Stanton, but no information on provenance.

did.unittitle: Witherell, H. M., Troy, New York, to William Duffy, Albany, New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: H. M. Witherell, M.D., wants give up his professional practice for that of the stage. He asks for a "trial." The letter was the gift of L. Cohen, Argosy Books, 1952.

did.unittitle: Wood, Laura, Washington, D.C., to William Henry Howell, Johns Hopkins

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She is writing a children's book on Walter Reed and asks Howell for details of Walter Reed's stay at Johns Hopkins studying physiology in 1881. The book was published as Laura Wood Roper, Walter Reed: Doctor in Uniform(New York: J. Messner, [1943]).

did.unittitle: [Woodford, William] Petition of John N---, Darlington, to Lord Henry, Earl of Lincoln, concerning William Woodford

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the salary of William Woodford, Professor of Physick at Oxford. Petititon was the gift of Dr. Richard Hunter, London, to John Fulton, 1956.

did.unittitle: Woodruff, Timothy L., Lieutenant Governor, Albany, to O. T. Osborne, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Osborne's effort to prevent his son, John Woodruff, from getting the measles, and what to do if he does get the measles. Letter sent to the Yale Medical Library after Osborne's death.

did.unittitle: Woodward, Joseph Janvier, Surgeon-General's Office, Washington, D.C., 4 letters to Jabez Hogg

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On medical microscopy and micro-photography. Woodward was one of the first physicians to apply micro-photography to pathology. Jabez Hogg was a British ophthalmologist.
Letters and a cabinet photograph of Woodward were purchased from Myers & Co., May 1954. Photograph has been transferred to the Library's photograph collection.

did.unittitle: Wright, Frank W., New Haven, to N. O. B. Wingrete [?], Secretary of the Wisconsin Board of Health

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wright was the Health Officer of New Haven.

did.unittitle: Young, Thomas, Selkirk [England], to John Bostock, Liverpool

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is partly about religion and his willingness to go to plays and to dance. Letter was purchased by John Fulton from Gurney and given to the Library in October 1955.
